bestBHT.bht: On a high mountain, a cloud swiftly covered the cap and overshadowed them all. As they entered into the cloud, the disciples became filled with fear. The cloud's presence was a symbol of the divine, much like the Shekinah-cloud that represented God's manifestation among His people. This event of entering the cloud was significant, representing a direct encounter with the divine that only a select few had ever experienced.

Henry Alford: Notice however the remarkable word chosen of the correct text.
In which places only in the New Testament the term is applied to the Son of God.
Compare also Ps. lxxxix. 3. 19: Isa. xliii. 10 (cited in Matt. xii. 18).
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the Shekinah-cloud, the pavilion of the manifested presence of God with His people"
this voice we heard, when we were with Him in the holy mount
Marvin Vincent: A strange peculiarity has been noticed about Hermon, in the extreme rapidity of the formation of cloud on the summit." (Edersheim)
Overshadowed them [επεσκιαζεν]. A beautiful imperfect: 'began to overshadow them;' thus harmonizing with the words, 'as they entered into.'" (Commentator)
The cloud, as a symbol of the divine presence, rests on these three as a sign to the disciples." (Commentator)
Philip Schaff: The fear was a growing one.
Culminating as the voice was heard.
Archibald T. Robertson: On Hermon as on many high mountains a cloud will swiftly cover the cap.
This same verb is used of the Holy Spirit upon Mary.
All six 'entered into' the cloud, but only Peter, James, and John 'became afraid'.
John Gill: While Peter was making the above request, before an answer was returned, a cloud appeared, a very uncommon one, as a symbol of the divine presence.
They feared as they entered into the cloud.
John Wesley: A cloud came and overshadowed them all. And they, the apostles, feared, while they (Moses and Elijah) entered into the cloud, which took them away.

bhtAttempts.bht: On a high mountain, a cloud swiftly covered the cap, overshadowing Peter, James, and John. The cloud's manifestation was a symbol of the divine presence, just as the Shekinah-cloud represented God's presence among His people. As the disciples entered into the cloud, they became filled with fear, emphasizing the magnitude of the moment. The fear grew as a voice spoke, culminating in the disciples being overtaken by awe. This event of entering the cloud was significant, as it signified a direct encounter with the divine that only a select few had experienced.

On a high mountain, a remarkable cloud swiftly covered the cap, overshadowing Peter, James, and John. This cloud, a symbol of the divine presence, was comparable to the Shekinah-cloud that represented God's manifested presence among His people. As the disciples entered into the cloud, they were filled with fear, experiencing a unique and awe-inspiring encounter. This event of entering the cloud reflected a select few's direct encounter with the divine, evoking a deep sense of reverence and wonder.
